pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body:
if the sender has already been dropped, `changed` will immediately resolve, effectively always taking that branch. We often drop the sender in our tests. The documentation is not very clear about it

> If the newest value has already been marked seen, then the method sleeps until a new message is sent by the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) connected to this Receiver, or until the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) is dropped.

but this is effectively the behavior that we (@rnijveld  and I) observed

issue.title: how to disable backward jump ?
issue.body:
if ntpd can `tinker stepback 0`

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35068445/is-there-a-way-to-ensure-ntp-synced-clock-never-moves-backwards

> Let say I have code that uses the clock to generate ids. Or I have code that calculates time elapsed since an event happened. Or any other logic that expects system time to only move forwards, never backwards. If time does move backwards, and the program notices it, lets say it crashes or hangs.
>
> I'd like to use an NTP service with such programs. Is there a way that NTP can be configured so that it is guaranteed never to adjusts time backwards? Slowing down the system clock would be fine.

comment.body: There is no good way to do this currently, I have reworked our configuration mechanism a bit in the above PR to start allowing this. Once this lands in master, this issue should automatically be closed, and this will be possible on master by simply setting a 0 backwards panic threshold.

pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body: fun fact: when the sender of a `Watch` is dropped, the `recv` call immediately succeeds. That means that in tests, where we usually drop this sender with a `_ = ..` pattern match, the `run` function would just loop endlessly to the `reset` branch.

pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body:
if the sender has already been dropped, `changed` will immediately resolve, effectively always taking that branch. We often drop the sender in our tests. The documentation is not very clear about it

> If the newest value has already been marked seen, then the method sleeps until a new message is sent by the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) connected to this Receiver, or until the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) is dropped.

but this is effectively the behavior that we (@rnijveld  and I) observed

issue.title: how to disable backward jump ?
issue.body:
if ntpd can `tinker stepback 0`

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35068445/is-there-a-way-to-ensure-ntp-synced-clock-never-moves-backwards

> Let say I have code that uses the clock to generate ids. Or I have code that calculates time elapsed since an event happened. Or any other logic that expects system time to only move forwards, never backwards. If time does move backwards, and the program notices it, lets say it crashes or hangs.
>
> I'd like to use an NTP service with such programs. Is there a way that NTP can be configured so that it is guaranteed never to adjusts time backwards? Slowing down the system clock would be fine.

comment.body: There is no good way to do this currently, I have reworked our configuration mechanism a bit in the above PR to start allowing this. Once this lands in master, this issue should automatically be closed, and this will be possible on master by simply setting a 0 backwards panic threshold.

commits.message: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped

pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body: fun fact: when the sender of a `Watch` is dropped, the `recv` call immediately succeeds. That means that in tests, where we usually drop this sender with a `_ = ..` pattern match, the `run` function would just loop endlessly to the `reset` branch.

pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body:
if the sender has already been dropped, `changed` will immediately resolve, effectively always taking that branch. We often drop the sender in our tests. The documentation is not very clear about it

> If the newest value has already been marked seen, then the method sleeps until a new message is sent by the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) connected to this Receiver, or until the [Sender](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/sync/watch/struct.Sender.html) is dropped.

but this is effectively the behavior that we (@rnijveld  and I) observed

issue.body:
Bumps [libc](https://github.com/rust-lang/libc) from 0.2.135 to 0.2.136.
Release notes

Sourced from libc's releases.

0.2.136

What's Changed

  • Ignore arm-linux-androideabi on bors by @​JohnTitor in rust-lang/libc#2959
  • add some time functions on glibc and musl by @​SteveLauC in rust-lang/libc#2957
  • Add support for tvOS by @​thomcc in rust-lang/libc#2958
  • implement ifreq for linux by @​folkertdev in rust-lang/libc#2960
  • adds putenv call to win32. by @​devnexen in rust-lang/libc#2964
  • solarish: Fix libsendfile symbol dependency by @​pfmooney in rust-lang/libc#2970

  • add missing clockid_t on macOS by @​name1e5s in rust-lang/libc#2968

  • illumos: Remove obsolete (and private) a.out define by @​pfmooney in rust-lang/libc#2969

comment.body: There seems to be something really weird going on with the deprecation warnings here, as these constants (to me at least) seem like they shouldn't be going anywhere. Perhaps we should watch the discussion on https://github.com/rust-lang/libc/pull/2963

issue.title: linux fixes recvmmsg flags type for musl/emscripten.

comment.body: I came here from the deprecation warnings spitted out, but I am deeply unclear given the above discussion what the expected alternative going forward is. These constants still seem to exist in glibc, so under what name can we expect them in the future?

issue.title: how to disable backward jump ?
issue.body:
if ntpd can `tinker stepback 0`

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35068445/is-there-a-way-to-ensure-ntp-synced-clock-never-moves-backwards

> Let say I have code that uses the clock to generate ids. Or I have code that calculates time elapsed since an event happened. Or any other logic that expects system time to only move forwards, never backwards. If time does move backwards, and the program notices it, lets say it crashes or hangs.
>
> I'd like to use an NTP service with such programs. Is there a way that NTP can be configured so that it is guaranteed never to adjusts time backwards? Slowing down the system clock would be fine.

comment.body: There is no good way to do this currently, I have reworked our configuration mechanism a bit in the above PR to start allowing this. Once this lands in master, this issue should automatically be closed, and this will be possible on master by simply setting a 0 backwards panic threshold.

commits.message: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped

pull_request.title: handle sender of the reset channel being dropped
pull_request.body: fun fact: when the sender of a `Watch` is dropped, the `recv` call immediately succeeds. That means that in tests, where we usually drop this sender with a `_ = ..` pattern match, the `run` function would just loop endlessly to the `reset` branch.
